An Epistle to the reader. The end of this print is to present to thy view a most wise and pious speech, spoken to King James the Fifth of Scotland, by a councellor of his; the which having occasioned what is premised to it, I thought fit to let them come hand in hand to thee; ...

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Henry Hills and John Field, printers to His Highness,

notesStmt.note: Title from A1r. Text on A2r commences "It is a principle very incident to the natural desire of men, that whatsoever judgement they are of in things of religion, to wish that all were of the same minde with themselves; ..". The actual epistle begins on C1r: "Sir, amongst the many blessings your subjects enjoy under this your government, ..". It is excerpted from William Drummond's "History of Scotland", p. 210 (cf. B4v).
Annotation on Thomason copy: "Feb: 22: 1655", "This hath noe other title".
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
